title: When will the Moxie be open?
body: So, when is that theater of yours gonna open? When's opening night? When will the Moxie be open? When? When? When? I hear this question at least ten times a day from friends, family, media contacts, new acquaintances, complete strangers, and the occasional talking mailbox. Sometimes it bothers me, sometimes it doesn't. It all depends on the reaction of the person who asks me the question. For instance: Scenario 1 Not Dan: When's the theater going to open? Dan: That's a good question. I'm hoping to get the majority of the work done during the month of May so we can open in mid-to-late June. I'm working as fast as I can, but it really depends on how soon the sub-contractors get their work done. Not Dan: Weren't you supposed to originally open in March? Scenario 2 Not Dan: When's the theater going to open? Dan: That's a good question. I'm hoping to get the majority of the work done during the month of May so we can open in mid-to-late June. I'm working as fast as I can, but it really depends on how soon the sub-contractors get their work done. Not Dan: Uh huh. It seems that everytime I ask when you're going to be open, the date keeps getting pushed further and further back. You're never going to get open, are you? Scenario 3 Not Dan: When's the theater going to open? Dan: That's a good question. I'm hoping to get the majority of the work done during the month of May so we can open in mid-to-late June. I'm working as fast as I can, but it really depends on how soon the sub-contractors get their work done. Not Dan: Fuckin' sub-contractors! Let's go wash away our problems with some dark beer and a brillo pad. Dan: OK! You're the bestest talking mailbox EVER! Can you guess which scenario DOESN'T end with me clinching my fists so tightly that my palms bleed? As I was envisioning this post yesterday, I was primed and ready to write out a huge rant about how the theater will be ready when it's ready, and I'm working as hard as I can, and can't you see that my hands are bleeding, and for the last time, where's my hat?! The more I thought about it, the more angry I became. Then I smashed my finger with a hammer and everything stood still for a second. I wasn't mad at people for asking me when the theater was going to open - I was mad because I couldn't give them an answer. I was mad because the sub-contractors haven't started working yet. I was mad because I didn't have control over the project. And I'm still mad. When I spoke to Chris (GC) yesterday, I asked him when the HVAC work was scheduled to begin. He didn't know. The HVAC contractor hadn't given him an ETA. That was the same thing he told me last Thursday, last Monday, and the week prior to that. Now, don't get me wrong - this isn't Chris's fault. He's delivered on his end of the deal in a (somewhat) timely manner. The walls are up... or more specifically, the walls are framed. They can't be sheetrocked until 1) the HVAC guy does his job, and 2) the electrician does his. As the GC, it's Chris's job to coordinate the work of the sub-contractors. I wonder if I can call the HVAC and electrical guys and try to get an ETA from them... Funny story: the phone just rang. It was Chris. The HVAC guy should be starting tomorrow. *blushes* So... How about those Cardinals?! Seriously though, that's good news. My mood has been significantly lightened, but I'm not completely placated. Just as I finished typing that, Bogart spilled roughly 3 gallons of green diarrhea out of his butthole and onto the kitchen floor. That's the second time he's done that today! This post is bad/good luck, that's what it is!!! Everytime I say one thing, something bad, or good, happens. I bet I won't find $1,000 hidden in this Sunbelt granola bar wrapper... Damn.

comments.author: nicholas
comments.body:
That's the same thing that happens when you're doing a movie:

When will the script be finished?
Who's in it?
When's it filming?
When will it be edited?
When will it be in theaters?
When will it be on DVD?
When will you get paid for it?

Etc, etc, etc.

With all creative endeavors, there will always be those who ignore the process and demand the product.

Blech.
